abstract.p: As a researcher the author began to reflect on her role on a team project as she and her colleagues developed a research design and Letter of Intent (LOI) for submission to a funding agency. The area of research interest was interprofessional collaboration. The author and her colleagues intended to observe a team of health professionals collaborating in health care decisions. The research team had not worked together previously, which provided an ideal forum for observing their own collaborative development. The team’s observations and reflections might prepare them for observing the collaborative practices of other teams. However, they found collaboration difficult to put into practice. The reflection presented here is author’s alone. As the author pondered her role in the team, she found the economy of words in poetry forced her to explicitly think about and face, emotionally, the part she played in the team’s stilted collaborative efforts. As a team, the author and her colleagues continue to work at collaboration.

disp-quote.p: Together, team, partners, co-operate.
We answered a call for interest
Interprofessional collaboration was the theme
We gathered in a small boardroom, eager and keen
Brainstormed ideas and established a scheme
We read the literature gathered by the RA1
Searched for additions and wrote résumés
Our ideas were many, our disciplines reflected
A research design was slowly collected
I drafted a proposal, its barebones not yet embellished
A gap in the literature still to be established
Placed on a wiki where we all could participate
A handful only prepared to collaborate
A few of us continued the wiki to complete
Early 2009 the full proposal to replete
A week set aside for team members to contribute
But few answered the call. Too busy, disinterested, in refute?
Two members of the team always responded
Apart from a few, the majority absconded
Whether time, disinterest or merely diffidence
Increasingly obvious was oblivious reticence
To publications you often referred
Yet inserting the information you always deferred
Please include your suggestions was my refrain
Your deference to do so, was it disdain?
On reflection I wondered whether my influence
Contributed to the lack of buy-in and continuance
Was I too obstinate and insistent?
Despondence set in, though I tried to resist it
Time went by, the proposal set aside
The LOI languishing as I began to deride
The process we had entered and were yet to examine
Ourselves perhaps a case of collaborative famine
Perhaps as the lead I had not heeded
The ideas of others but instead had superseded
My own thoughts in their place
Did the team feel displaced, replaced, unneeded?
What had I done, did I take control?
Did my patience wear thin? Thrust into the role
Of drafting the proposal, was it my lack and failure
To involve the team, displacing them with my sole labor?
Anger at first was replaced with despair
I had hoped and wanted with the team to share
Ideas, and design a robust yet complex proposal
But many, I noted, weren’t sure of my disposal
Was I the researcher who claimed this expertise
Or an imposter unable to achieve
A project so complexly designed?
Whatever the reason, the team was resigned
An expert from away came in to teach
The skills required for the team to reach
A confidence level that inspired a step forward
The project was abridged and we moved onward
Cohesion of the team though we noted was lacking
Were we moving forward with each other’s backing?
Or will the lack of working together
Overturn our project? Will we collaborate never?

sec.title: Postscript
sec.p: Collaboration involves being open to other disciplinary and professional ideas. Yet even within one discipline, as Richardson (1996) has so eloquently written, there can be debate as to what constitutes its subject matter. Furthermore, qualitative research is still subject to disparagement by those who take a more positivist approach. Where then, does poetry sit as a research method? Faulkner (2009) has suggested that providing criteria for evaluating verse can assist those who question its use as research, a point echoed by Lahey (2011) in relation to lyric philosophy. Anchored in criteria for evaluating both science and art, Faulkner (2007, 2009) suggests that standards for assessing the quality of research poetry include artistic concentration, discovery, embodied experience, conditional, narrative truth, and new insight. My goal (Ellis, 2000) was to understand my experience as a member of the collaborative research team. I stumbled upon verse as a way to write. My attempts at prose lacked the depth of feeling I was able to better get at with the use of rhythm and alliteration. It was my embodied experience of working with the team I wanted to explore. Creating a poem forced a pensive dwelling-in-thought, which I have found absent in other forms of writing. Writing in verse facilitated an intense, reflective surfacing of previously inaccessible layers of tacit knowledge. The story encapsulated in the poem is partial and situated (Haraway, 1988); it is my story from my point of view, a sociologist and qualitative researcher on the team. The poem resonates with those who have read and reviewed it and, in another research project on collaboration, has identified for us those aspects of collaboration that are absent from the larger body of literature, namely, what is collaboration, and what are some of the difficulties in putting it in place? Lastly, as data generation, data analysis, and/or poetic transcription, poetry offers a new method of doing research that need not be a mere addendum to traditional research.

bio.title: Bio
bio.p: Raewyn Bassett is a sociologist and qualitative researcher in the health and social science fields. She teaches qualitative methods courses and seminars and conducts research projects on the use of qualitative software, qualitative methods, and tacit, performative practices. She is engaged in interprofessional, interdisciplinary, and intersectoral collaborations.
